commit.message:
Fix broken ASIO channel selector validation (i.e. only use when flag is set) (#885)

Validation for PaAsioStreamInfo currently fails if the channelSelectors field is null, even if the paAsioUseChannelSelectors flag is not set. This PR amends the check so channelSelectors is only validated if the paAsioUseChannelSelectors flag is set in PaAsioStreamInfo.

verification.payload:
tree 46a71b243695a84f26142617438370c2afaec047
parent 4600d814564c392ec848d4de9cb41e07aa9c16ba
author Evan Balster <evan@interactopia.com> 1709936766 -0800
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1709936766 +1100

Fix broken ASIO channel selector validation (i.e. only use when flag is set) (#885)

Validation for PaAsioStreamInfo currently fails if the channelSelectors field is null, even if the paAsioUseChannelSelectors flag is not set. This PR amends the check so channelSelectors is only validated if the paAsioUseChannelSelectors flag is set in PaAsioStreamInfo.

commit.message:
centralize clock handling for pthread_cond_timedwait (#877)

* Ensure that the clock that is configured on the cond var object is the one that is used to compute the wait deadline.

* Ensure that the most appropriate clock is selected on each platform based on availability CLOCK_BOOTTIME > CLOCK_MONOTONIC > CLOCK_REALTIME (on Mac use gettimeofday because other clock interfaces are either not available or broken).

NB: use GetSystemTimeAsFileTime on Windows. should be much faster than GetSystemTime+SystemTimeToFileTime according to http://www.windowstimestamp.com/description. thanks s09bQ5

Used directly or indirectly by pa_jack, pa_alsa, pa_asihpi

Resolves #795, #807.

verification.payload:
tree d5e8eadafd10f3b432f65d5ebdb77ecbc6fd476a
parent 45c12e8d18ae4434000ed1521e49d9b5ef91dedf
author Ross Bencina <rossb@audiomulch.com> 1708728957 +1100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1708728957 +1100

centralize clock handling for pthread_cond_timedwait (#877)

* Ensure that the clock that is configured on the cond var object is the one that is used to compute the wait deadline.

* Ensure that the most appropriate clock is selected on each platform based on availability CLOCK_BOOTTIME > CLOCK_MONOTONIC > CLOCK_REALTIME (on Mac use gettimeofday because other clock interfaces are either not available or broken).

NB: use GetSystemTimeAsFileTime on Windows. should be much faster than GetSystemTime+SystemTimeToFileTime according to http://www.windowstimestamp.com/description. thanks s09bQ5

Used directly or indirectly by pa_jack, pa_alsa, pa_asihpi

Resolves #795, #807.

commit.message:
dsound: don't restrict the host buffer to 16-bit (#774)

Currently, the DirectSound Host API code only creates 16-bit integer
DirectSound buffers. All audio data provided by the user is therefore
converted by PortAudio to and from 16-bit, regardless of the user buffer
format.

This basically makes it impossible to pass 24-bit audio through the
DirectSound Host API.

If the user buffer format is not 16-bit, this also causes pointless
conversions to take place, *even if the hardware is running at 16-bit*,
because modern Windows versions (Vista+) convert the data to floating
point behind the scenes before it is handed off to the hardware. This
can lead to silly situations where 32-bit float samples from the user
are (lossily) converted to 16-bit by PortAudio, then ended off to
Windows via DirectSound, only to be converted back to 32-bit float
again, before finally being converted to the format the hardware device
is configured to use. This can easily lead to two layers of
16-bit dithering (one from PortAudio, and one from Windows) being piled
on top of each other, resulting in an elevated noise floor.

This commit fixes this problem by configuring the DirectSound buffers to
use the same format as the user buffer. This should stop PortAudio from
converting samples in all cases except paInt8, which is not supported by
WAVEFORMATEX (only paUInt8 is).

The new code assumes that DirectSound will accept whatever format we
throw at it. I feel confident that this is always true on Vista+
regardless of hardware, because starting from Vista DirectSound does not
access hardware directly - it always goes through the Windows Audio
Engine which supports all formats in both directions (I verified this
using paloopback).

The consequences of this change on pre-Vista Windows are less clear,
although [1] suggests that this might just work even on 2000/XP as
KMixer should be able to handle these conversions as well.

[1]: https://microsoft.public.win32.programmer.directx.audio.narkive.com/elgNlPIn/

Fixes #54

verification.payload:
tree 26c1851f764565e946b8001203aab968820b582f
parent 0451480762826119511b5b7e0636b6d31362b978
author Etienne Dechamps <etienne@edechamps.fr> 1703288272 +0000
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1703288272 +1100

commit.message:
pulseaudio: fix PaPulseAudio_Initialize unlocking (#852)

Make sure that if PaPulseAudio_Initialize fails that
a) Mainloop is unlocked if HostAPI is initialized
b) Unlocking is done before freeing
c) It's done only once

Also move allocations group freeing code to correct place
now there only one place where it's called.

Fixes #848

tree f3e23a696640c8d81a2b3b922dcd35dacfa2d99e

committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1703285446 -0800

pulseaudio: fix PaPulseAudio_Initialize unlocking (#852)

Make sure that if PaPulseAudio_Initialize fails that
a) Mainloop is unlocked if HostAPI is initialized
b) Unlocking is done before freeing
c) It's done only once

Also move allocations group freeing code to correct place
now there only one place where it's called.

Fixes #848

commit.message:
wasapi: Fix wrong sign in timeInfo.inputBufferAdcTime calculation. (#850)

ADC capture time must be earlier than currentTime, as the capture
time of any received samples in a buffer must be in the past.

Fix the wrong sign in calculation to fix this.

Signed-off-by: Mario Kleiner <mario.kleiner.de@gmail.com>

verification.payload:
tree e773094b6227a6a8a752b648d92a7908bcffebdf
parent 4af3321f4896d1f79e843cb8a60141271b7299c4
author kleinerm <mario.kleiner.de@gmail.com> 1698693794 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1698693794 +0200

wasapi: Fix wrong sign in timeInfo.inputBufferAdcTime calculation. (#850)

ADC capture time must be earlier than currentTime, as the capture
time of any received samples in a buffer must be in the past.

Fix the wrong sign in calculation to fix this.

Signed-off-by: Mario Kleiner <mario.kleiner.de@gmail.com>

commit.message:
pulseaudio: Make use of suggestedLatency stream parameter. (#849)

This will translate the client provided suggestedLatency from
seconds to microseconds and pass them to Pulseaudio, so
the client has some control over required latency.

Invalid (= negative) values get mapped to requesting minimum
supportable latency, ie. 0 milliseconds.

This replaces the previous hard-coded latency of ~2 msecs,
which turned out to be too low on some tested mid-range
systems and caused audio buffer underruns and audio artifacts.

Signed-off-by: Mario Kleiner <mario.kleiner.de@gmail.com>

verification.payload:
tree 05b4c12fdf526f17088e06d138f1adf59d3b0675
parent 24c8d575e588d557d28f4011becb753421346860
author kleinerm <mario.kleiner.de@gmail.com> 1698677928 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1698677928 +0200

pulseaudio: Make use of suggestedLatency stream parameter. (#849)

This will translate the client provided suggestedLatency from
seconds to microseconds and pass them to Pulseaudio, so
the client has some control over required latency.

Invalid (= negative) values get mapped to requesting minimum
supportable latency, ie. 0 milliseconds.

This replaces the previous hard-coded latency of ~2 msecs,
which turned out to be too low on some tested mid-range
systems and caused audio buffer underruns and audio artifacts.

Signed-off-by: Mario Kleiner <mario.kleiner.de@gmail.com>

commit.message:
wdmks: declare GUIDs with selectany attribute (#846)

* wdmks: declare GUIDs with selectany attribute

Match the behavior of guiddef.h in both mingw and the Windows SDK headers. This prevents linking errors caused by multiply defined symbols when linking against certain Windows SDK libs (like dxguid.lib).

* Make sure this works even if DECLSPEC_SELECTANY is not defined

---------

Co-authored-by: Ross Bencina <rossb@audiomulch.com>

verification.payload:
tree 76aa81f403ebcd1f791eeab67011a694887eb621
parent 6c9e455887993e1c1cf8c83239bfb5b2fc84d521
author invertego <invertego@users.noreply.github.com> 1696633321 -0700
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1696633321 +1100

wdmks: declare GUIDs with selectany attribute (#846)

* wdmks: declare GUIDs with selectany attribute

Match the behavior of guiddef.h in both mingw and the Windows SDK headers. This prevents linking errors caused by multiply defined symbols when linking against certain Windows SDK libs (like dxguid.lib).

* Make sure this works even if DECLSPEC_SELECTANY is not defined

---------

Co-authored-by: Ross Bencina <rossb@audiomulch.com>

commit.message:
Fix 'pulseaudioHostApi' use-after-free/null ptr deref in PaPulseAudio_Initialize (#847)

The call to PaPulseAudio_UnLock( pulseaudioHostApi->mainloop ) in error-label is performed on 'pulseaudioHostApi' after 'pulseaudioHostApi' has been freed by PaPulseAudio_Free and set to NULL.

parent ba3f91faf27508c534d5fe706894369c3f5b3322

committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1696631462 +1100

Fix 'pulseaudioHostApi' use-after-free/null ptr deref in PaPulseAudio_Initialize (#847)

The call to PaPulseAudio_UnLock( pulseaudioHostApi->mainloop ) in error-label is performed on 'pulseaudioHostApi' after 'pulseaudioHostApi' has been freed by PaPulseAudio_Free and set to NULL.

commit.message:
pulseaudio: Move Pulseaudio include in correct place when using autoconf (#843)

As Jack and Pulseaudio both needs Ringbuffer that include can
be done in same place. In configure.in also Pulseaudio header
file was included before it was sure that it was really needed.

Commit makes sure that Pulseaudio include is available only if
it's needed as it can cause failing in build if Pulseaudio
develoment files are not available.

verification.payload:
tree 45c75bbfc3aecdf6f296c478a86e9a96b5207660
parent 0dce0e9cf5c2235f04f2caeb2ca09db358cb8a6e
author Tuukka Pasanen <tuukka.pasanen@ilmi.fi> 1696093928 +0300
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1696093928 -0700

pulseaudio: Move Pulseaudio include in correct place when using autoconf (#843)

As Jack and Pulseaudio both needs Ringbuffer that include can
be done in same place. In configure.in also Pulseaudio header
file was included before it was sure that it was really needed.

Commit makes sure that Pulseaudio include is available only if
it's needed as it can cause failing in build if Pulseaudio
develoment files are not available.

commit.message:
mme: don't restrict the host buffer to 16-bit

Currently, the MME Host API code only creates 16-bit integer MME
buffers. All audio data provided by the user is therefore converted by
PortAudio to and from 16-bit, regardless of the user buffer format.

This basically makes it impossible to pass 24-bit audio through the
MME Host API.

If the user buffer format is not 16-bit, this also causes pointless
conversions to take place, *even if the hardware is running at 16-bit*,
because modern Windows versions (Vista+) convert the data to floating
point behind the scenes before it is handed off to the hardware. This
can lead to silly situations where 32-bit float samples from the user
are (lossily) converted to 16-bit by PortAudio, then ended off to
Windows via MME, only to be converted back to 32-bit float again, before
finally being converted to the format the hardware device is configured
to use. This can easily lead to two layers of 16-bit dithering (one from
PortAudio, and one from Windows) being piled on top of each other,
resulting in an elevated noise floor.

This commit fixes this problem by configuring the MME buffers to use the
same format as the user buffer. This should stop PortAudio from
converting samples in all cases except paInt8, which is not supported by
WAVEFORMATEX (only paUInt8 is). This is pretty much the same idea as
#774.

The new code assumes that MME will accept whatever format we throw at
it. I feel confident that this is always true on Vista+ regardless of
hardware, because starting from Vista MME does not access hardware
directly - it always goes through the Windows Audio Engine which
supports all formats in both directions (I verified this using
paloopback).

On pre-Vista Windows, this should still work all the way back to Windows
98 SE, because MME goes through KMixer which supports all formats [1].
Nevertheless, it's difficult to be sure, so this code checks the Windows
version it's running on and preserves the old behavior (i.e. always use
Int16) on pre-Vista Windows.

[1]: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/drivers/audio/background-of-non-pcm-support#waveout-api

Fixes #139

Fix MSVC warning C4018 signed/unsigned mismatch (#821)

See #810

verification.payload:
tree 9b45c0cad9d15e7608aa4b3b996895c0721605d4
parent e951915d05d90d08dd759fa7636c22c250ca685d
author Etienne Dechamps <etienne@edechamps.fr> 1689374165 +0100
committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1689374165 -0700

commit.message:
bindings/cpp: CMake: support pkgconfig with RelWithDebInfo (#822)

bindings/cpp: add  `RelWithDebInfo` to the configurations allowed to install portaudiocpp.pc, otherwise you won't have support for pkg-config when building a release package with separate debugging information. Besides that, RelWithDebInfo is identical to Release.

commit.message:
wasapi: Add passthrough support (AC3, E-AC3, ...) (#778)

* add AC3 and E-AC3 passthrough support for wasapi
* Use WAVEFORMATEXTENSIBLE_UNION to contain PCM and SPDIF specific structures and clearly differentiate between PCM and SPDIF modes configuration.
* Made implementation generic and added all other known passthrough formats.
* Known issues documented in #816
Resolves #778
Co-authored-by: Dmitry Kostjučenko <dmitrykos@neutroncode.com>

committer GitHub <noreply@github.com> 1684536362 +1000

wasapi: Add passthrough support (AC3, E-AC3, ...) (#778)

* add AC3 and E-AC3 passthrough support for wasapi
* Use WAVEFORMATEXTENSIBLE_UNION to contain PCM and SPDIF specific structures and clearly differentiate between PCM and SPDIF modes configuration.
* Made implementation generic and added all other known passthrough formats.
* Known issues documented in #816
Resolves #778
Co-authored-by: Dmitry Kostjučenko <dmitrykos@neutroncode.com>

commit.message:
Add cmake files for cpp bindings (#721)

- cmake script is standalone and does not depend on the main cmake script
 - cmake script also configures a legacy pkg-config file
 - include files are installed in /include/portaudiocpp as it was done before
 - added new portaudiocpp.pc.in in the cmake folder, specific to the cmake configuration
 - cmake script should be compatible to add_subdirectory find_package and fetchcontent

Add cmake files for cpp bindings (#721)

- cmake script is standalone and does not depend on the main cmake script
 - cmake script also configures a legacy pkg-config file
 - include files are installed in /include/portaudiocpp as it was done before
 - added new portaudiocpp.pc.in in the cmake folder, specific to the cmake configuration
 - cmake script should be compatible to add_subdirectory find_package and fetchcontent

commit.message:
Remove some warnings from allowlist (#812)

These warnings are not currently being triggered. Their presence is
probably the result of merge confusion between #780 and #799.

commit.message:
Treat warnings as errors on CMake CI (#780)

* Add a CMake option to turn warnings into errors

The option is disabled by default as it can get in the way of people
merely building PortAudio (as opposed to doing development work). This
is provided as a CMake option so that it can easily be switched on by
people doing local development. (The option is turned on in CI.)

In this mode pre-existing warnings are suppressed, in other words they
are "grandfathered" in for the sake of preventing build breakage. The
idea is to enable enforcement first to prevent backsliding, and then we
can take care of existing warnings later.

* Enforce no warnings through the CMake CI

This will prevent backsliding by failing CI on any code that produces
new types of warnings.

Treat warnings as errors on CMake CI (#780)

* Add a CMake option to turn warnings into errors

The option is disabled by default as it can get in the way of people
merely building PortAudio (as opposed to doing development work). This
is provided as a CMake option so that it can easily be switched on by
people doing local development. (The option is turned on in CI.)

In this mode pre-existing warnings are suppressed, in other words they
are "grandfathered" in for the sake of preventing build breakage. The
idea is to enable enforcement first to prevent backsliding, and then we
can take care of existing warnings later.

* Enforce no warnings through the CMake CI

This will prevent backsliding by failing CI on any code that produces
new types of warnings.
